intro: Galium glabrum var. hirsutum, commonly known as hairy bedstraw, is a low-growing herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, often hairy stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in clusters, typically from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are usually ovate to lanceolate in shape and may have a slightly hairy texture. Hairy bedstraw is often found in moist, disturbed soils and can thrive in woodland or grassland habitats.
